results.title: Chemical changes
results.creator_credit: Beryl Denman Lacey and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Digestion”.
An account of the chief changes involved in the chemical breakdown of the main types of food during digestion. Shows the secretion of saliva and its action on cooked starch; the gastric glands; secretion of intestinal bile and pancreatic juice and their effect on proteins, carbohydrates and fats; the absorption of nutrients through the villi and lacteals into the blood and its subsequent circulation through the body.

results.title: Chemical bonding and atomic structure. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Roger Mazur, Mel Waskin, Coronet Films and Don Lane Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
The substances forming our world are composed of atoms held together by powerful electrical forces called chemical bonds. The physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds depend on the nature of these bonds. Discusses metallic, ionic, covalent and interatomic bonds and forces dealing with ions, atoms, crystals, valence, polarity and Van der Waals forces. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Chemical bonding
results.creator_credit: David W. Ridgway, J. Arthur Campbell, National Science Foundation and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Explains chemical bonding in terms of electric interactions that cause the bonding in the hydrogen molecule. The release of energy when H atoms combine to form H2 on a platinum surface is shown. This energy change is related to the similtaneous attraction of electrons by two or more nuclei, opposed by electron-electron repulsions. Through animation the quantum mechanical view of electron distribution is portrayed. The bonding interaction between two hydrogen atoms is contrasted to the very weak, non-bonding interaction between two melium atoms. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David W. Ridgway, J. Arthur Campbell, National Science Foundation and Davidson Films

results.title: Chemical bond and atomic structure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
Discusses the structure of the atom and shows how the electrons help determine the way in which the atom bonds chemically with other atoms. Shows three types of chemical bonding and explains how bonding affects substance. (Suitable for years 11-12)

results.title: Chelsea Football Club
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and British Information Services
results.brief_description: Behind the scenes and on the field with the Chelsea Football Club. The men and methods behind the organization of this well-known club are pictured, and the training required for players in both the main and reserve teams is described. Ends with an exciting Saturday afternoon league game.

results.title: Chelsea flower show '98
results.creator_credit: Nigel Farrell, Two Four Productions, Royal Horticultural Society (Great Britain) and Julia Runagall
results.brief_description: The Chelsea Flower show is a triumph of man, and his gardening skills, over the potential disasters of nature. The 5 day 1998 Chelsea Flower Show, held in the grounds of the Royal Hospital, saw a record number of entries with 770 of the world’s finest horticulturists vying for the prestigious R.H.S. Gold medal. This video is the official souvenir video and offers behind the scenes interviews with entrants and many of the visitors to the show that was broadcast daily on live television. Presented by Alan Titchmarsh.

results.title: Chelsea College
results.brief_description: This film concerns the theoretical and practical instruction received by students at the College of Aeronautics and Automobile Engineering in Chelsea, England, and the practical application of their highly skilled technical knowledge in many fields of present day life. The students coming from over forty-five different countries are divided into three training groups - automobile, aeronautical, and agricultural engineering. In addition to showing a good deal of detail of the training given, the film displays scenes of the student life out of the class-rooms.

results.title: Cheetah
results.creator_credit: Jane Chermayeff, Peter Chermayeff and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Examines, without commentary, the physical characteristics and behavior of African animals in their natural environment, including the fleeting cheetah in action on the Serengeti Plains of Tanzania as it hunts its favourite prey, the Thompson’s gazelle. Develops skills of self expression and encourages independent thought in relating visual experiences to creative activities. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Cheek to cheek
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Strong Arm Films and Beth Armstrong
results.brief_description: When her uncommunicative, elderly husband dies suddenly after choking on an Anzac biscuit, Beryl casts off her bereavement to rediscover pleasures she had lost touch with in the latter years of her marriage, such as swimming in the sea, tap dancing, chocolate and foolish games. The catalyst for her reinvigoration so late in life is her little dog, who metamorphosises before her eyes only, into a frisky, carefree older woman. The pair become inseparable playmates much to the consternation of Beryl’s uptight daughter who sees only a spoilt dog and fears for her mother’s sanity. A film that touches on universal themes such as life after death of a loved one, caring for the aged, discovering your other half and taking control of your own happiness. Cast includes Melissa Jaffer, Tina Bursill, Maggie Blinco and Georgina Naidui.

results.title: Cheechako's first day
results.creator_credit: Film Loft Productions and Derek W. Muirden
results.brief_description: Shows the debut of a polar bear cub in an Oregon zoo, his reactions to new surroundings, the subtle ways in which the mother bear cares for and trains her cub, and the ways in which these animals adapt to the urban environment. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
